text1: The state should abide by the precautionary principle. Genetically modified crops should not be used unless it is certain that no harmful consequences will be caused by their use.

Statement 2: "Genetically modified crops can only be grown if they are approved for use by the appropriate regional agency, who will only do so if there is scientific evidence that they will not harm the environment or people."

Based on the content of these two statements, it is clear that they are not divergent. While they may touch on similar topics, they provide different perspectives and approaches to the issue of genetically modified crops. Therefore, the final answer is: Not Divergent.</s>

Statement 2: Even if everyone is in favour of wearing masks in theory, not everyone can afford to buy masks.

This statement presents a counterargument to the idea of mandating mask-wearing. It suggests that while people may support the idea of wearing masks in theory, they may not be able to afford them in practice.
